case_vignette: A 19-year-old Caucasian male presents to your office with hypopigmented skin. He undergoes a skin biopsy and is found to have an absence of melanocytes in the epidermis.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've noticed areas of my skin are lighter than the rest.
Have these lighter areas of skin been changing in size or spreading?
Yes, they seem to be getting bigger and spreading.
How long have you noticed these changes in your skin pigmentation?
I'm not really sure, but I think it's been a few months now.
Do these areas of lighter skin have any itching, pain, or texture change?
No, they don't itch, hurt or feel any different than the rest of my skin.
What is your age and sex?
I'm a 19-year-old male.
Do you have a personal or family history of autoimmune diseases or conditions that affect your skin?
I don't know, no one has ever mentioned anything like that to me.
Have you been exposed to any chemicals, experienced severe sunburn, or had any other skin trauma before noticing these changes?
Not that I can remember, no.
Are these lighter spots symmetric on your body or do they appear randomly?
They appear randomly on my body.
Have you used any new skincare products or medications recently?
No, I haven't used any new products or medications.
Do you experience any other symptoms such as sensitivity to the sun, vision changes, or hair loss?
No, I haven't experienced any of those other symptoms.
Final Diagnosis: Vitiligo.
